emphasis.docTitle:
On the publication year of Sericini genera and species described by Brenske in “Die
Serica
-Arten der Erde” ( Coleoptera : Scarabaeidae : Sericinae)

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Museum A. Koenig, Leibniz Institute for the Analysis of Biodiversity Change (LIB), Adenauerallee 127, 53113 Bonn, Germany .
Biology Centre CAS, Institute of Entomology, Branišovská 31, CZ-370 05 České Budějovice, Czech Republic .

subSection.paragraph:
The year of publication of Brenske’s species and genera described in his opus “Die
Serica
-Arten der Erde” is updated following up an overlooked delay of some of the fascicules of the Berliner Entomologische Zeitschrift, namely the volumes 42, 43, and 46. This change affects 201 species group names and 20 genus group names, many of which have been revised in the past three decades, but no change of priority of other names occurred. The spelling of
Mericserica oberthueri Brenske, 1899
is corrected.
Key words. Scarab chafers , publication year , Africa , Asia

Species catalogues, including other online data collections, have an increasing role for online databases such as the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) or the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI). These works are also often highly cited (if citable). On the other hand, some of these are quite prone of errors and lack citable cornerstones such a DOI or publication date. The problem becomes greater when they are copied between the various internet sources. Sometimes their original data or entries are lost, which makes many internet sources rather untrustworthy. For Sericini ( Coleoptera : Scarabaeidae : Sericinae), there are two recent world catalogues, one by Krajcik (2012) and the other by Schoolmeesters (2023) . In addition, more focused catalogs are available for the Palearctic region ( Ahrens 2006b , 2007b ; Ahrens & Bezděk 2016 ) and for the New World ( Evans & Smith 2009 ).

While updating the Palaearctic catalogue of
Sericini ( Ahrens & Bezděk 2016 )
, we came across a problem regarding the year of publication of many of Brenske’s taxa. This resulted from overlooked publication delays of fascicles of Ernst Brenske’s “Die
Serica
-Arten der Erde” in volumes 42, 43, and 46 of the Berliner Entomologische Zeitschrift ( i.e. , Brenske 1898 , 1899, 1902; Table 1 ). This delay affected fascicles (Hefte) 3 and 4 of these volumes, from the respective years 1897, 1898, and 1901, which were all published in the subsequent year, respectively. The problem affects 201 species group names and 20 genus group names, of which many have been revised in the past three decades by D.A.

To clearly revise all publication dates and to generate awareness of these corrections, which fortunately do not affect any changes of synonymy due to altered priority, as well as to refer to recent taxonomic revisions being affected by these corrections, we decided to focus a separate paper to the necessary adjustments.

All names of genus and species group affected by the updates and correction of the publication year are listed along their entire reference list in order to provide a complete correction loop for all those citations. We also provided the full list of respective references. We followed this more exhaustive approach to ensure that updates are not overlooked. All corrected publication dates are indicated by an asterisk (*).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Updated publication dates of Brenske’s chapters of “Die
Serica
-Arten der Erde” (Figs. 1–2). Parts with delayed publication whose publication year is here corrected are marked in the column “corrected publication year” in bold and with an asterisk (*).

Remarks. Brenske (1898: 355) included the name
Chrysoserica
with
Mericserica
(in Brenske 1898 : unavailable name) in the same couplet and gave no further morphological differentiation, nor included a species name with
Chrysoserica
. Consequently, according to Article 12 ( International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature 1999 ) the name
Chrysoserica ( Brenske 1898 )
is not available. A complete description, including species names, was published in the next fascicle ( Brenske 1899a ). The genus was recently revised by Ahrens (2001a) .

FIGURE 1. Title pages of fascicules of Brenske’s volumes of “Die
Serica
-Arten der Erde” (part 1–4). Arrows indicate the delayed publication date of volumes 42 and 43.

FIGURE 2. Title pages of fascicules of Brenske’s volumes of “Die
Serica
-Arten der Erde” (part 5–7). Arrows indicate the delayed publication date of volume 46. Below left side: Portrait of Ernst Brenske (1845–1904; from: https://www.zobodat. at/personen.php?id=16972&bio=full).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks.
Cyphoserica
was grouped by Brenske (1898) in the same couplet with two other genera, Emphania Blanchard, 1850 and
Euphoresia
(in Brenske 1898 : unavailable name), while it was not mentioned elsewhere nor in association with any species name. Thus, the genus name became available only after Brenske (1900a) properly diagnosed it in a key.

Remarks.
Doxocalia
was grouped by Brenske (1898) in the same couplet with two other genera,
Bilga Fairmaire, 1893
and
Thrymoserica
(in Brenske 1898 : unavailable name), while it was not mentioned elsewhere nor in association with any species name. Thus, the genus name became available only after Brenske (1900a) properly diagnosed it in a key.

Remarks.
Euphoresia
was diagnosed by Brenske (1898) in the same couplet with two other genera, Emphania Blanchard, 1850 and
Cyphoserica
(in Brenske 1898 : unavailable name) while it was not mentioned elsewhere nor in association with any species name. Thus, the genus name became available only with Brenske (1900a) when it was properly diagnosed in a key.

Mericserica Brenske, 1899a
*: 321
( type species by monotypy:
Mericserica oberthueri Brenske, 1899
*, see below);
Dalla Torre 1912: 39

Remarks. Brenske (1898: 355) presented the name
Mericserica
along with
Chrysoserica
(in Brenske 1898 : unavailable name) in the same couplet. Because there was no further morphological differentiation nor an indication of species included in
Mericserica
, the generic name was unavailable until Brenske (1899a) properly diagnosed it in a key. The genus was recently revised by Ahrens (2004a) and Ahrens & Fabrizi (2016) , however, the genus name was misspelled as Meriserica in these works.

.
Arrow 1946b: 266 , Dalla Torre 1912: 20 ; Pope 1960: 547 , 549.

Examination of the type specimens of
Serica piceorufa
revealed that the species is related to the
Neoserica uniformis
group rather than with other “
Autoserica
” species. The exact identity of
Serica piceorufa Fairmaire, 1888
is uncertain, as the only type specimen available for examination was a female. So far, no species of the
Neoserica uniformis
group has been recorded near Beijing ( type locality of
S. piceorufa
). However, the wide, trapezoidal labroclypeus with dull base and the transversely produced antennomere 7 of female are, apart from the short and wide metatibia, unique diagnostic features that
Serica piceorufa
shares with the
Neoserica uniformis
group. This is why we continue to apply the name
Autoserica Brenske, 1898
to this lineage (as a subgenus, at least until the polyphyletic conundrum of
Neoserica
sensu lato species is resolved by a more robust molecular phylogeny).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. The publication date for
Serica renardi Ballion, 1871
had to be emended from 1870 to 1871. The description of
S. renardi
appeared in volume 43 (for 1870) of the Bulletin de la Société Impériale des Naturalistes de Moscou. Numbers 1 and 2 were published in 1870, while numbers 3 and 4 (containing the description of
S. renardi
) were delayed and printed in 1871, as clearly stated on the title page of the journal for numbers 3 and 4.
